    return 'The mystery of quantum superposition begins with the revolutionary double-slit experiment conducted by Thomas Young in the early 19th century.
    This experiment demonstrated that light can exhibit characteristics of both particles and waves as it passed through two slits and propagate interfering waves.
    These waves' superposition creates an interference pattern revealing light's dualism not understood until the advent of quantum mechanics in the 20th century.

    Fast forward to the early 1920s, when the Schrödinger equation was introduced.
    This mathematical equation describes quantum superposition by showing how a particle's wave function evolves over time.
    Crucially, this equation allows for a system to exist in multiple states simultaneously until a measurement is made — one of the cornerstones of quantum mechanics, and the principle upon which quantum superposition stands.

    Expanding this single particle superposition to a system of particles gives rise to entanglement, another quintessential facet of quantum computation.
    These entangled states provide the exponential calculation capacity leap over classical computers.

    However, the promise of quantum computing is not without challenges.
    Superposed states are notoriously delicate.
    They can be easily destroyed or "decohered" by external influences, making quantum error correction one of the most daunting tasks.
    Recent advancements in quantum error correction codes and fault-tolerant quantum computation strategies provide substantial solutions, though the implementation still requires resources exceeding current experimental capabilities.

    Quantum superposition also poses profound questions about the nature of reality.
    In the famous Schrödinger's Cat thought experiment, a cat is put in a quantum superposition of being both alive and dead until an observer checks – implying that the very act of observation affects reality.
    This has resulted in varied interpretations of quantum mechanics from the Copenhagen interpretation, advocating observer-induced collapse, to the Many Worlds interpretation, suggesting every possible outcome happens in a separate universe.

    As we advance into the new epoch of quantum computation, it is incumbent on us to continue to explore, and attempt to reconcile the theory with reality.
    Quantum superposition, in its heart, contains the essence of the quantum world - its peculiarities, its challenges, and its immense promise.

    The future of quantum superposition and quantum computing is boundless; whether it's advancing our understanding of the universe, enhancing cybersecurity, stimulus for advancements in material science, or solving intractable computational problems.
    Harnessing quantum superposition for quantum computing signals the dawn of a new era in human technological progress.
    The feasible integration of quantum superposition into viable quantum computers will, no doubt, redefine the trajectory not just of quantum computing but also the broader arena of quantum mechanics.'
